Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Democratic Participation in Non-Democracies? Mobilizing International Legal Regimes for National Reform in Three Monarchies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Are there mechanisms through which non-democracies can be made more accountable to their citizens? One such mechanism may be the human rights monitoring process built into international treaties. States that ratify human rights agreements are obligated to submit reports to monitoring bodies about the steps taken to bring their domestic practices into line with the treaties. When a state submits a report, the monitoring bodies invite non-governmental organizations within the state to comment on whether the state's report is accurate. State reports and NGO feedback are periodically reviewed in a formal session, after which the monitoring body issues its own assessment of state compliance. In these ways, domestic NGOs have an opportunity to put indirect pressures on their states by providing information to the monitoring bodies on the states' compliance with human rights law. This process of citizen feedback is particularly salient in states with underdeveloped democratic institutions. This project analyzes the role of human rights treaties and their monitoring bodies in providing opportunities for domestic NGOs to pressure the state through a comparative analysis of Morocco, Jordan and Bahrain; three monarchies that offer limited opportunity for citizen participation in the legislative process but that have ratified human rights treaties that involve these monitoring processes. Reports on state compliance with treaties on rights of women and labor, and interviews with civil society activists and attention to NGOs' use of human rights monitoring to channel domestic pressure for national reform all allow evaluation of citizen feedback concerning human rights treaties.

This research will discover the extent to which human rights monitoring mechanisms serve to empower citizens of states with underdeveloped democratic institutions, an issue of widespread interest. Comparative case studies allow us to explore how the international community can more effectively support citizen empowerment in aspiring democracies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study suggests an alternative way of thinking about and measuring the impact of human rights treaties as civil society empowerment rather than asstate compliance. While the current literature on human rights treaties focuses on state compliance, this project shifts attention to the impact of the treaty monitoring process on domestic civil society. When states sign onto human rights treaties, they obligate themselves to undergo periodic monitoring that includes international review of a state report on treaty implementation. These monitoring sessions also include domestic civil society feedback on the accuracy of state reports on treaty implementation. Through this process, the international monitoring body becomes a type of arbitrator of claims made by the state and by domestic civil society about state human rights practices. In other words, the treaty monitoring process sets in motion a process of civil society feedback that is particularly striking in autocratic contexts where domestic feedback is severely limited. This feedback not only assists in the monitoring of “top down” state compliance, but perhaps more significantly, it enables a form of “bottom up” civic engagement with the state. The ongoing debate over the impact and value of human rights treaties needs to be broadened to include the “civil society empowerment effect” that emerges from international monitoring.

Rather than solely an instrument of treaty implementation, I propose that the treaty monitoring process should be more broadly conceptualized as a forum in which the state and domestic civil society engage each other outside the boundaries of the state, potentially empowering civil society vis-à-vis the regime. In other words, treaty monitoring can become a platform for domestic dissent and can generate a degree of government accountability to civil society that may not transpire on the domestic level, especially in authoritarian states. I term and refer to this process of domestic civil society confronting its state about the content of national policy through the monitoring mechanisms of international law as “transpositional feedback”: the feedback from the people to the government is transposed from the national to the international stage. 

The study finds at least four byproducts of the monitoring process that constitute mechanisms of empowerment for domestic civil society. Focusing on two stable autocracies (Bahrain and Qatar) and one stable democracy (Finland), this study draws upon observational, interview and archival research to outline and describe "the 4 C's" of civil society empowerment via human rights monitoring: conclusions, credibility, coalitions and communication. COMMUNICATIONrefers to the way in which the monitoring process can provide a way for domestic constituencies to communicate their with government when such communication is not possible at home (Qatar). Even in stable autocracies with a modicum of (constrained) civic expression (Bahrain), the type of direct communication about state's human rights practices that is facilitated by the monitoring process is often less likely to occur domestically. The monitoring committee's validation of information provided by domestic NGOs also provides CREDIBILITY to human rights defenders and their claims. In addition, domestic NGOs often form COALITIONS to submit joint reports to the monitoring body and these coalitions can strengthen civil society vis-a-vis the state. Finally, the CONCLUSIONS of the monitoring committee provide ammunition for domestic civil society to follow up with their state after the monitoring period.
